item.question:
Consider the above exhibit.
You want to remove the file -x from the directory listing shown in above exhibit.
Which of the following commands can you use to remove the file?
item.hint: It is not the shell that will consider <font face="monospace">-x</font> as a special item. Hence, escaping <font face="monospace">-x</font> for the shell will not have the desired effect. In this case you will need to make it clear to the command <font face="monospace">rm</font> that <font face="monospace">-x</font> should not be interpreted as an option.

item.question: Which of the following commands allows you to read the content of a directory?
item.hint: Many commands on UNIX/Linux are abbreviated. For example, the command <font face="monospace">cp</font> stands for <font face="monospace">copy</font>. By determining the actual name of the command it usually makes it clear what action the command will perform when executed.

item.question: Which of the following is not stored in an inode?
item.hint: File names are only meant to make it easier for humans to handle files. The Operating System uses the inode numbers to handle the files.

item.question: What is the meaning of the sticky bit permission on a directory?
item.choice: It has no meaning when used on a directory.
Prevents users from deleting the directory.
The kernel will keep the directory in memory to improve performance.
Allows files within the directory only to be removed by the owner, owner of the directory, or a user with root privileges.
item.correct_answer: Allows files within the directory only to be removed by the owner, owner of the directory, or a user with root privileges.
item.hint: A directory that usually has the sticky bit permission is <font face="monospace">/tmp</font>.

item.question: What will the above command do when executed in a shell?
item.choice: Generate an error, as the command <font face="monospace">cut</font> has no knowledge of an option <font face="monospace">-u</font>
Writes a list of all logged in users to the file <font face="monospace">namen.txt</font> and prints the same list sorted to screen.
Writes a list of all logged in users to the file <font face="monospace">namen.txt</font>
Will first execute the command <font face="monospace">who</font>, then execute <font face="monospace">cut</font>, and at last will execute the command <font face="monospace">sort</font>.
item.correct_answer: Writes a list of all logged in users to the file <font face="monospace">namen.txt</font>
item.hint: In een zogenaamde pipe-constructie wordt de uitvoer van het linker commando gekoppeld aan de invoer van het rechter commando. Het <font face="monospace">></font>-teken koppelt de uitvoer van het commando aan een bestand. Er is echter maar één stroom aan data, of te wel waar gaat de uitvoer van het commando <font face="monospace">cut</font> naartoe? Het bestand of naar het commando <font face="monospace">sort</font>?
